quiz.title: Economics: Factors of Production, Scope, and Demand

questions.question: Machines and tools are examples of:
questions.explanation: Machines, tools, and equipment are physical capital used in production.

questions.question: Which of the following comes under macroeconomics?
questions.explanation: Per capita income is a macroeconomic measure of average income per person in a country.

questions.question: Law of demand states that:
options: Price has no effect on demand
questions.explanation: The law of demand says that, all else equal, as the price of a good increases, quantity demanded decreases.

questions.question: A rightward shift of demand curve shows:
questions.explanation: A rightward shift means that at each price, consumers are willing to buy more—an increase in demand.

questions.question: When an individual’s income rises, when everything else remains the same, his demand for normal goods:
options: Any of the above is possible
questions.explanation: For normal goods, demand increases as income rises, all else equal.

questions.question: When the price of the substitute commodity of X falls, the demand for X:
options: All of the above is possible
questions.explanation: If the price of a substitute falls, consumers switch to the cheaper substitute, reducing demand for X.

questions.question: If the quantity demanded remains unchanged as the price of the commodity falls, the coefficient of price elasticity of demand is:
questions.explanation: If quantity demanded does not change when price changes, demand is perfectly inelastic (Ed = 0).

questions.question: If the income elasticity of demand is greater than one, then the commodity is:
questions.explanation: Income elasticity > 1 indicates a luxury good (demand changes more than proportionally to income).

questions.question: If the amount of the commodity purchased remains unchanged when the price of another commodity changes, the cross elasticity of demand between them will be:
questions.explanation: Cross elasticity = 0 means the goods are unrelated (change in price of one does not affect demand for the other).

questions.question: Which of the following is an exception to the law of demand?
questions.explanation: Giffen goods violate the law of demand because demand increases when price rises.

questions.question: The law of diminishing marginal utility was popularized by:
questions.explanation: Alfred Marshall formally stated and popularized the law of diminishing marginal utility in his principles of economics.

questions.question: If the income elasticity of demand for a commodity is found to be 0.4, then the commodity concerned is:
questions.explanation: Income elasticity between 0 and 1 indicates a necessity (demand rises less than proportionally to income).

questions.question: Which of the following are not transaction costs?
options: Costs of lawyers certifying the sale of an apartment
Costs of renovating a new apartment
The cost of finding a suitable agent to sell the apartment
Costs for appraising the price of an apartment
questions.explanation: Renovation costs are improvements to the property, not costs directly related to executing the transaction itself.

questions.question: Which of the following accurately describes the concept of the “natural rate of unemployment” and its significance for monetary policy?
options: The rate of unemployment that can be achieved without causing inflation to rise
The lowest possible rate of unemployment an economy can achieve
The rate of unemployment that results from cyclical factors
The rate of unemployment targeted by central banks to maintain economic growth
questions.explanation: The natural rate of unemployment (NAIRU) is consistent with stable inflation; monetary policy aims to stabilize unemployment around this level.

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of a central bank's open market operations?
options: To control the money supply and interest rates
questions.explanation: Open market operations (buying/selling government securities) are a key tool for influencing money supply and interest rates.

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of an automatic stabilizer in the economy?
options: Unemployment benefits increasing as more people lose their jobs
Interest rate cuts by the central bank
questions.explanation: Automatic stabilizers work without new legislation; unemployment benefits rise automatically during downturns, supporting demand.

questions.question: Consider an economy experiencing both high inflation and high unemployment, a situation known as stagflation. Which of the following policy mixes would be most appropriate to address both issues simultaneously?
options: Increase interest rates and decrease government spending
Increase government spending and decrease interest rates
Implement structural reforms to enhance productivity and apply targeted fiscal measures to support employment
Decrease taxes and increase money supply
questions.explanation: Stagflation requires supply-side solutions (structural reforms to boost productivity) combined with targeted support to avoid worsening inflation or unemployment.

questions.question: A linear production possibility frontier:
options: Means that there is a constant opportunity cost when increasing the output of one good
Means that there is an increasing opportunity cost when increasing the output of one good
Means that there is a decreasing opportunity cost when increasing the output of one good
Means that there is no opportunity cost when making an economic choice
questions.explanation: A linear PPF indicates constant opportunity cost—resources are equally suited to producing either good.

questions.question: An economy currently experiences full employment with a very tight labour market, and a balance of trade surplus. Which of the following policies would be most appropriate?
questions.explanation: Appreciation reduces trade surplus and cools inflationary pressure in a tight economy—consistent with internal and external balance.

questions.question: If an economy grows above its trend rate, and experiences a rapid increase in aggregate demand, which of the following two economic problems are likely to result:
options: A trade deficit and rising inflation
A trade surplus and a budget deficit
A trade deficit and rising unemployment
questions.explanation: Overheating leads to inflation (demand > supply) and trade deficit (imports rise due to strong domestic demand).

questions.question: Which of the following is not associated with supply-side policy?
options: Reducing the marginal rate of tax to increase incentives
questions.explanation: Devaluation is a demand-side tool (affects net exports). Supply-side policies focus on improving productive capacity.

questions.question: Assuming other factors remain constant, a fall in the exchange rate for a country's currency is most likely to:
options: Cause an economy to go into recession
Increase a country's aggregate supply of goods and services
Reduce the import prices of foreign goods
Increase the number of people who are unemployed
questions.explanation: Depreciation boosts net exports (X-M) and thus aggregate demand, which can stimulate output and employment in the short run.

questions.question: Quantitative easing is the common name for which policy instrument?
options: Asset selling by a Central bank
Asset purchasing by a Central Bank
Lowering interest rates by the Monetary Policy Committee
Lowering the interest rate at which Commercial banks lend to each other
questions.explanation: Quantitative easing involves a central bank buying financial assets to inject money into the economy when interest rates are near zero.
